text.title: And it was after the death of Moses:

pasuk.text: This is connected to the order of the Torah which ends with Moses’ passing, and this follows it.

If he were alive, I would prefer him. The Rabbis interpret this passage as a reference, not to Moses the leader, but to Moses the Lawgiver, concerning the 3,000 laws that were forgotten during the period of mourning for Moses. Joshua came and asked the Lord to repeat these laws to him. Said to him the Holy One, Blessed be He: Moses My servant has died, and the Torah is called by his name, implying to you that it is impossible [to convey them to you.] Go out and occupy them with martial activities.

text.title: Every place on which [the soles of your feet] will tread:

pasuk.text: A similar statement to this was said to Moses, concerning which we learned in Sifrei : If this verse is to teach about the boundaries of Eretz Israel, the Scripture already states: From this desert and Lebanon etc., [clearly defining the boundaries of the Holy Land.] If so, why is it stated, ‘Every place where your foot will tread?’ Even outside of Eretz Israel. [I.e.] After you have conquered the land, all that you will conquer outside the land, will be holy and will be yours.

[I.e.] the Desert of Kadesh, the Desert of Zin [that is near Edom], which was in the southeastern corner, through which they entered the land, as it is stated: And behold, we are in Kadesh. Now, whence is it derived that it was in the southeast? For it is stated: And the south side shall be to you from the desert of Zin near Edom etc.

text.title: to the great river, the Euphrates:

pasuk.text: This is its width from south to North.

text.title: all the land of the Hittites:

pasuk.text: is included.
Lengthwise from east to west.
in worldly pursuits, as the Scripture states: “For you will cause this nation to inherit the land.”

text.title: Just be strong and very courageous:

pasuk.text: in Torah, as the Scripture states: “To observe and to do in accordance with all of the Torah.”
The book of Deuteronomy was before him.
והגית. Every expression of הגיון in the Scriptures refers to the heart, as it is stated: “And the meditation of my heart (והגיון לבי) before you.” Your heart will meditate (יהגה) fear.

text.title: Did I not command you, be strong and have courage:

pasuk.text: in war; as it is stated: Do not fear and not be dismayed. Now, when did he command him? In Moses’ time, as it is stated: “And command Joshua, etc.”
on the day that the days of the weeping in the mourning of Moses were ended.

everything necessary for the way. He told them to prepare weapons for battle. For, if you say it refers to food and drink, were they not supplied by the manna which was in their vessels until Nissan 16? For so it is stated: “And the manna ceased on the morrow.”
[lit. in yet three days, i.e.] At the end of three days, when you will still be here three days, and afterwards you will cross.
among you shall cross over armed.

text.title: toward the rising of the sun:

pasuk.text: The eastern side of the Jordan.
defy your words.

text.title: And Joshua [the son of Nun] sent [two men out of Shittim to spy]:

pasuk.text: Against my will I must say that he dispatched them during Moses’ mourning period, for after three days following the termination of Moses’ mourning period, they crossed the Jordan, for thence we deduced that Moses died on Adar 7 by counting back thirty-three days from the day they came up from the Jordan, namely, the tenth day of the first month. Now, of necessity, from the time the spies were dispatched, they did not cross the Jordan until the fifth day, as it is stated: and stayed there three days until the pursuers returned. On that night they crossed over and came to Joshua the son of Nun, and Joshua rose up early in the morning, and they moved from Shittim, here is a fourth day. And they lodged there before they crossed over. Hence, they did not cross until the fifth day.

Secretly. So did Jon. render it. He said to them: Disguise yourselves as deaf-mutes (חרשים) so that they will not conceal their affairs from you. Another explanation is: חרש [with a “shin”] is like חרש [with a “sin” or “samech,” namely pottery.] Load yourselves with pots so that you appear as potters.

text.title: and see the land and Jericho:

pasuk.text: Now, was Jericho not included in the generalization? Why, then, is it specifed? Because it was as strong as all of them [the cities combined], it was situated on the boundary. Similarly, and there were missing of David’s servants nineteen men and Asahel. Now, was Asahel not included in the generalization? Why, then, was he specified? Because he was as strong as all of them [combined]. Similarly, and King Solomon loved many foreign wives and Pharaoh’s daughter. Now, was Pharaoh’s daughter not included in the generalization? Why, then, was she specified? Because he loved her as much as all of them [combined]. And regarding the sin, since she caused him to sin more than all of them. This was taught in Sifrei.
זונה. Targum Jon. renders: Innkeeper, one who sells various foodstuffs (מזונות).
לחפר [lit. to dig,] to spy. And similarly: Thence he sought (חפר) food.

[lit.“and had hidden him.”] Some Scriptural passages treat the plural as singular. [In this case,] because she hastened to hide them, and [she hid them] in a narrow place as though they were one man. The Agadic Midrash of Rabbi Tanhuma states: They were Phinehas and Caleb, and Phinehas stood before them, yet they did not see him because he was like an angel. Another explanation is: And she hid him, [i.e.,] each one by himself. And we have found the like thereof: Oil and incense make joyful the heart. (ישמח לב), sing. form.) And it is not written ישמחו לב (plural form), [implying that each one makes the heart joyful.]
With their capsules.
the place for crossing the water, for they thought that they had turned back towards the Plains of Moab, and the Jordan stood in between.
[I.e.,] the gatekeepers.

text.title: nor did there remain (or arise) anymore spirit:

pasuk.text: And there did not remain anymore spirit, even to lie with a woman. [This was evident to Rahab] because, as the Rabbis said: There was neither prince or ruler who had no relations with Rahab the harlot. She was ten years old when the Israelites departed from Egypt, and she practiced harlotry for forty years.
That you will make, so that when you come and conquer the city, that you will recognize the sign and let me live.

text.title: And she let them down by a rope through the window:

pasuk.text: [lit., by] the [rope.] By this very rope and window the sinners would ascend to her. She said: “O Lord of the universe! With these I have sinned. With these forgive me.”
There sprouted in Rahab an expression of Divine Spirit that they would return at the end of three days.
We are making this matter dependent upon you to make this sign.
תקות - an expression of a line (קו) or rope.

text.title: his blood shall be upon his head:

pasuk.text: The guilt of his slaying will be upon his own head, for he will have caused his own death.

text.title: his blood shall be upon our head:

pasuk.text: The guilt of his slaying will be upon us.
the Jordan.

This journey differs from other journeys, for whereas previously, in the days of Moses, the pillar of cloud would lead the way, the Ark following in the very middle of the camp after two divisions, [comprising the first six tribes, had passed], now the Ark would travel ahead.

[This is explained in inverted order.] Since they are all descended from Levi, Amram’s grandfather, they are called Levites, as our Sages explain in Gen. Rabbah.: in forty-eight places, the priests were called Levites, this being the reason for it.

text.title: But there shall be a distance:

pasuk.text: This is respect for the Omnipresent.

The same as ובינו and between it, and similar to this: “Let Israel rejoice in his Maker” (בעשיו). Another explanation is: And between them, referring to the Holy Ark and the ark of Joseph’s remains, which were traveling together.
so that you be permitted to go and pray before it on the Sabbath. Thus it is explained in M.T. for he knew that they would besiege Jericho on the Sabbath.
This is connected with, “And go after it.”

text.title: for you have not passed this way before:

pasuk.text: You have not gone in this manner until now.
On the third day. And the thirtieth day of Moses’ mourning period was the first of the three days.
Prepare yourselves.
when you cross the Jordan.
Jonathan renders: wonders.

text.title: And Joshua said to the priests:

pasuk.text: on the morrow.

text.title: Carry the Ark of the Covenant:

pasuk.text: Until now the Levites carried it, but today the Priests.

text.title: When you come to the edge of the waters of the Jordan:

pasuk.text: when you enter within its edge.

text.title: you shall stand still in the Jordan:

pasuk.text: until all the people cross to the other side.
He confined them all between the two staves of the Holy Ark. This is one of the instances wherein a small space contained a large quantity.
Since you see that all of you are confined here.

text.title: the covenant of the Lord of all the earth:

pasuk.text: The covenant of the Holy One, Blessed be He, Who is the Lord of all the earth. Now, do not wonder about the ‘he’ of הברית [the covenant which should read ארון ברית] for many Scriptural passages are worded in this manner, such as המסגרות המכונות the borders of the bases, and העמק הפגרים the valley of the corpses.
[עובר is interpreted in the sense of] preceding you to enter into the Jordan.
Prepare them to be ready for that which I shall command them when you will cross the Jordan.

text.title: the waters that come down from above:

pasuk.text: downstream, as is the manner of all flowing rivers.
When the water flows downstream to the place where it will be cut off, it will not flow down farther, but will be gathered and heaped and will ascend to form stacks upon stacks.
נד, Like: He gathers like a heap (כנד), A heap of harvest (נד), an expression of height. In this manner Menahem (the grammarian) joined them together.
גדותיו, an expression of a high bank.
for the days of Nissan are the harvest season.
From the place where they [the Israelites] stood, they [the waters] were cut off.
So was its name.
Those that had previonsly flowed downstream from there.
They flowed on their course like all streams that flow into the sea, until they were completed.
stood by the bank of the Jordan.

text.title: in the midst of the Jordan:

pasuk.text: and as long as they stood, the upper waters did not flow downstream, and during this time, all the people were crossing on the dry ground.
standing precisely opposite one another.
They are the aforementioned, who were to be prepared.

text.title: and you shall carry them over with you:

pasuk.text: in accordance with Moses’ commandment to build an altar there with on Mt. Ebal and to write upon them the words of the Torah. On that very day, they came to Mt. Ebal, built therewith the altar, and offered up burnt offerings and peace offerings, and they ate and drank and peeled them and came and lodged in Gilgal.
Enter now into the Jordan and pass until you are in front of the priests.
in Gilgal as a memorial of this.
I.e. others Joshua set up in the midst of the Jordan.

as we learned in Tractate Sotah While they were still standing in the river bed of the Jordan, Joshua said to them: Know for what purpose you are crossing the Jordan. On the condition that you drive out all the inhabitants of the land etc.

text.title: And it was, when all the people had completely passed over, that the Ark passed over, etc.:

pasuk.text: not after the manner in which the others had passed over, but as it is explained below in this episode, the soles of the priests’ feet were lifted up backwards to the dry land on the bank from which they had entered, beside which they were standing, and the waters returned backwards to flow as it had done heretofore. Hence, the Ark and its bearers are found to be on one side, and all Israel on the other side. The Ark picked up its bearers and passed over.

text.title: in the presence of the people:

pasuk.text: [lit. before the people,] i.e. before the eyes of the people.
Here the Scripture explains the aforementioned, how the Ark of the Lord and the priests passed over in the presence of the people etc.

text.title: that they come up out of the Jordan:

pasuk.text: that they cross, is not written here, but “that they come up.” Hence, we deduce that they came up on the bank beside which they were standing. And it is impossible to say that they were standing beside the western bank of the Jordan, for it is stated above: The feet of the priests were dipped in the edge of the water. And there it is stated: And the priests stood and all Israel passed.

text.title: the soles of the priests’ feet were lifted up:

pasuk.text: from the water to the dry land which was beside them, and the waters returned to their place. Hence, the Ark is found to be on one side and Israel on the other side. Accordingly, the Ark lifted its bearers and passed over. And concerning this matter, Uzzah was punished when he took hold of the Ark. If it bore its bearers, can it not be deduced by a fortiori conclusion that it can bear itself?
That is the lodging place where they lodged that night.

text.title: who were on the side of the Jordan westward:

pasuk.text: on the side to which the children of Israel had crossed, i.e. the west side. And previously, they had been on the east side.

חרבות צרים, according to Targum, sharp knives, also “You have turned back the edge of his sword.” When the sharp edge is turned sideways and does not cut well. And so: “Every weapon which will be sharpened against you.”

for they had already circumcised a large assembly on the night of their departure from Egypt, and this was the second time, for the entire forty years that they were in the desert, the north wind did not blow for them, and they did not have any day suitable for circumcision, as we learned in Job. Our Rabbis state, however, “ ‘the second time’ refers the uncovering the corona at circumcision,” [i.e. splitting the membrane and pulling it back] which Abraham was not commanded to do.
It was given this appellation to commemorate the event, because the foreskins were made into a sort of mound, or hillock.

Through speech he circumcised them. He said to them, “Do you expect to inherit the land while being uncircumcised? Was it not thus stated to Abraham: 'And you shall keep my covenant etc. And I shall give to you and to your seed after you the land of your sojournings?’ ”

text.title: all the people that came out:

pasuk.text: Not one of them was here, for they had all died, and they were circumcised, as it is stated: for… were circumcised.
as I explained, that the north wind had not blown, and they were the ones who were circumcised now.

text.title: And their children whom he raised up in their stead:

pasuk.text: i.e. And their children whom he raised up in their stead, (they are the ones who were born in the desert) them Joshua circumcised.

text.title: and they remained in their places:

pasuk.text: in their places (Jonathan) and they did not besiege the city.
from the wound.

I removed the reproach of the Egyptians who had said, “See that ‘Ra-ah’ is before your faces. There is a star named ‘Ra-ah’ which is a symbol of blood. We see it over you in the desert.” And that is what Moses said in the desert, “Why should the Egyptians say, With ‘Ra-ah’ He took them out.” But they did not know that that was the blood of circumcision. And when they circumcised in Joshua’s time, and that blood came, that reproach was removed, for the vast multitude which had gone up with them were still vexing them. In this manner, Rabbi Moses the preacher expounded.
גלותי - I have removed, like “(גל) Remove [or roll away] from me reproach and shame.” “ (ויגל) and he rolled off [or removed] the stone.”

text.title: on the morrow of the Passover:

pasuk.text: the day of the waving of the 'Omer, for first they sacrificed the 'Omer. And from the seventh of Adar, when Moses died, whereupon the manna ceased to fall, they subsisted on the manna which was in their vessels, which they had gathered on the seventh of Adar, as it is stated: “the manna they ate forty years.” Now, was it not forty years less thirty days, for the beginning of the falling of the manna was on the fifteenth of Iyar? Hence we deduce that in the cakes which the Israelites took with them from Egypt they perceived the taste of manna.

text.title: neither had the children of Israel manna anymore:

pasuk.text: Therefore, they ate of the grain of the Land. Had they still had manna, they world not have eaten of the grain, for the manna was pleasing to them. An appropriate parable is: One says to a child, why do you eat barley bread? Because he has no wheat bread. Therefore, it is stated: “Neither had the children of Israel manna anymore, etc.”
Hence we deduce that the outskirts of a city are considered as part of the city, for it is impossible to say [that he was actually] inside Jericho.
Have you come to support us?

to your aid, for no man can wage war against it [Jericho] and seize it, to throw down the wall. But in the time of Moses your master, I came and he did not want me, as it is stated: “if Your presence does not go, etc.”

text.title: the captain of the Lord’s host:

pasuk.text: Israel, who is the Lord’s host. Now, this was Michael, as it is said: “Michael your prince.”

text.title: had shut its gates and was barred:

pasuk.text: according to Targum , closed with iron gates and reinforced with copper bolts.
Heb. הַיּוֹבְלִים.
with the final blast, when the blower lengthens the note.
Heb. תַּחְתֶּיהָ [lit.,] under it.

The children of Reuben and the children of Gad were passing before them, because the children of Gad were mighty warriors and would strike with a strong arm, as it is said: “And he tears the arms, even the crown of the head.”
the tribe of Dan that traveled last, and they would gather up all those who lingered behind.
It was the Sabbath.

text.title: And the city shall be devoted:

pasuk.text: consecrated [belonging to “Hekdesh”]. For the day was the Holy Sabbath; hence it was appropriate that the booty which was taken thereon be consecrated.
Heb. וַעֲכַרְתֶּם, an expression of turbid water (מַיִם עֲכוּרִים).

text.title: And the young men who were spies went in:

pasuk.text: here they needed speed, and therefore acted as lively young men. On the first night they were like angels, for they kept themselves from sinning with Rahab the harlot. Therefore, there they were called מַלְאָכִים [lit., angels]. And therefore, they were called men, angels, and young men.

text.title: with [the loss of] his first born shall he lay its foundation, and with [the loss of] his youngest son:

pasuk.text: At the beginning of the foundation which he builds therein, his first born son will die and he will bury him, and continue [to bury all his sons] until the youngest one dies at the finish of the work, viz. the setting up of the gates.
[lit., with Beth aven.]

text.title: on the east side of Beth-el:

pasuk.text: מִקֶּדֶם.
until they broke them.

text.title: Would that we had been content:

pasuk.text: Would that we had decided to dwell on the east side of the Jordan in the land of Sihon and Og, which has already been conquered.

text.title: and what will You do for Your great Name?:

pasuk.text: which is inherent in our name [i.e., Israel, the שַׂר, or prince, of God.] This is the derash. The peshat is: What will You do for the Name of Your might which has already become famous? For now they will say, His strength has become weakened.

The kethib is קֻם לָ [It has arisen, or stayed, for you.] That which you have prayed before Me and mentioned, has stood you in good stead. Another explanation is: You stayed in camp, and did not go out with them, while I said: “And who will lead them out [to battle] and who will bring them [back].” “For you shall bring the children of Israel and I shall be with you.” “For he will cross before this nation and he will cause them to inherit.” If you go before them, they will succeed, and if not, they will not succeed. Another explanation is: קוּם לָ, [explaining לָ as: On your account] On your account this has befallen them. I did not tell you to consecrate the booty of the city.
One family contained many households.
by heads; all the men of the household were to come to the casting of lots.
The tent and the movable property.

text.title: he and all that he has:

pasuk.text: according to the law specified below: He and the cattle by lapidation. The accent zakef which appears over the word: בָּאֵשׁ [with fire] indicates that it is separate from אֹתוֹ [he]; for we find verses which the accent divides, such as: הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ אַחֲרֵי דֶרֶ מְבוֹא, “far past [the Jordan], the way of the going down of the sun,” in which אַחֲרֵי [far past] is separated from דֶרֶ [the way] by the accent. And this is its interpretation: And he that is taken with the accursed thing shall be burned with fire that which is fit to be burned, as is explained below.

text.title: He and all that he has:

pasuk.text: according to the law explained below. This is a brief verse, and similar to it: “whosoever smites the Jebusites and gets up to the tower.” He does not explain what will be done to him. In (I) Chronicles, however, he explains: ‘shall be chief.’ Here also, he did not specify what would be done to ‘him and all that he has,’ and below he specifies.

before the ‘hoshen,’ the place where the [names of] the tribes were inscribed. And the Holy One, Blessed be He, gave him a sign that the tribe which sinned, his stone would fade; and Judah’s stone faded.

text.title: and he brought near the family of Judah:

pasuk.text: to a casting of lots. He brought near the heads of the families, one man from each family, and they cast lots on whom it would fall, and afterwards on each household, i.e., one man of each household came to the lot casting, and afterwards all the men of that household came.

He began to criticize the method of casting lots [by which his guilt had been established]. He said: By casting lots are you coming upon me [to establish my guilt]? If a lot were cast between you and Eleazar the two greats of the generation, it would fall on one [of you]. Said he to him: “I ask you not to find fault with the method of casting lots, through which method the land is destined to be divided.”
He saw the children of Judah [his tribe] assembling for war [in loyalty for one of their own]; and said [to himself]: It is better that I alone die rather than many thousands of Israel be killed.

text.title: and thus and thus have I done:

pasuk.text: also with other devoted things during Moses’ time, as it is stated: “and I will devote their cities.”

text.title: When I saw among the spoils:

pasuk.text: I reflected upon that which is written in the Torah: “And you shall eat up she spoils of your enemies.”

As the Targum renders: a Babylonish garment, for any sovereign who had not acquired a palace in the Land of Israel, experienced no satisfaction from his reign, as it is stated: “And I give you a coveted land, an inheritance desired by hosts of nations.” And the king of Babylonia had a palace in Jericho, and when he would come here he would wear them (sic).

text.title: and they ran to the tent:

pasuk.text: lest the tribe of Judah arrive first and take it from there to cast a doubt on the efficacy of the lots.

And they melted them. And our Rabbis state: He threw them down before the Omnipresent. He said before Him, “Lord of the Universe, For these [insignificant articles] shall the majority of the Sanhedrin fall?”

text.title: and his sons, and his daughters:

pasuk.text: to witness his chastisement, and so that they be deterred from doing as He [had done].

text.title: and his ox and his ass:

pasuk.text: to destroy them, as it was said: And it shall be, he that is taken with the accursed thing shall be burned with fire, he and all that he has.
for he had violated the Sabbath.
the tent and the movable property.
the ox and the [other] animals.

text.title: only you shall take as spoils to yourselves:

pasuk.text: do not cause the spoils to be “cherem” [doomed] anymore [as you did in Jericho].

Heb. הַתִּיֵקְנוּ, an expression of תִּיק, a sheath, i.e., until we have taken them out of the sheath [the protection afforded them by the fortifications of] the city. Defourrer in Fr. [to unsheathe, from fourreau, a sheath]. We may also interpret it as an expression of נְתִיקָה, drawing out, as: Draw them out like flocks to the slaughter.

text.title: on the west side of Ai:

pasuk.text: for Ai was on the east side of Beth-el and Beth-el was on the west side of Ai.

text.title: and Joshua lodged among the people:

pasuk.text: to be ready early in the morning.
as the Omnipresent had said to him: “If he crosses before them they will cross and if not, they will not cross.”

text.title: And he took about five thousand men:

pasuk.text: one ambush, following the other ambush, closer to the city than its fellow.
This setting is an expression of preparation near the wall, to wage war, as it is stated concerning the son of Hadad in (I) Kings (20:12): “Set upon the city. And they set.”
Heb. עֲקֵבוֹ their liers in wait, like: “For he has tricked me (וַיַּעַקְבֵנִי)”

text.title: And Joshua went that night into the midst of the valley:

pasuk.text: Our Rabbis said that he lodged in the depth of the Law.
At the time of day which they had planned [or been advised] on the preceding day, “at that time we will go out,” for they were soothsayers and diviners.
Heb. וַיִּנָּגְעוּ, an expression of a plague [or beating]. [Jonathan renders] and were broken. They showed themselves as though they were beaten before them.
This was the signal for the group lying in ambush to emerge from the ambush when they would see the spear stretched out toward the city. espada in Spanish, a sword.
lit., hands.

text.title: and the people that fled to the desert:

pasuk.text: The Israelites who fled to the desert, as it is stated above, turned back to fight upon the pursuers.

text.title: And the others came out of the city:

pasuk.text: the ambush who had set fire to the city.
This section is written in the manner of ‘earlier’ and ‘later’ [events combined], for on the day they crossed the Jordan he did so.

text.title: And he wrote there on the stones:

pasuk.text: They are the aforementioned stones. After this event [of building the altar] they peeled the lime off them and brought them to Gilgal.

text.title: to bless the people of Israel first:

pasuk.text: to pronounce the blessings before the curses: Blessed be the man who will not make a graven or molten image.

text.title: And they also acted with wile:

pasuk.text: Just as Jacob’s sons dealt cunningly with Hamor the father of Shechem who was a Hivite; and the inhabitants of Gibeon were also from the Hivites, as it is stated in this episode. וַיִּצְטַיָּרוּ - They made themselves like message carriers, from the expression of: “ (וְצִיר) And a messenger was sent among the nations.” Now, every word, the beginning of whose root is ‘zade,’ when it is used as reflexive in the form of מתפעל or נתפעל, a ‘teth’ comes in the middle thereof, and separates the root letters of the word, like: מַה נִּצְטַדָּק ‘How will we justify ourselves?’ from the root צדק, [that he says נִצְטַדָּק,] and so: גשמה יִצְטַבַּע ‘his body will be bathed,’ from צבע.
so that they should appear like people coming from a distant land.
a synonym for מְבַקְּעִים, split., This is an Aramaic expression, as דחיטי ציריה, ‘the splits of the wheat kernels,’ דמיצרי זיקי, ‘which split the sacks.’

text.title: and all the bread… was dry and mouldy:

pasuk.text: arsin in French, an expression of מוּקָד, burned [or toasted], and so did Jonathan render כִסְנִין.

text.title: Perhaps you dwell in my midst:

pasuk.text: Perhaps you are from the inhabitants of the land?
Heb. הִצְטַיַּדְנוּ, an expression of צֵידָה provisions, i.e., when we took it out for provisions for the journey.

text.title: And the men took of their provision:

pasuk.text: They accepted their words for they captured them with their mouths [מִצֵּידָם meaning from their hunting or capturing] an expression of: “and he who did not (צֵידָה) hunt.”

He recited a song instead of the sun, since he bade the sun, “Be silent,” i.e., be silent [by refraining] from reciting [your] song. And as long as it is silent, it stands still and does not continue on its orbit, for all the time of its revolution it recites [its] song. The simple explanation of the verse is, however, (דּוֹם) is an expression of waiting, like: “if they say thus to us, ‘wait!’” (דּוֹמוּ) , and so, “wait (דּוֹם) for the Lord.”

text.title: and moon in the valley of Ajalon:

pasuk.text: At that time, the moon was standing opposite the valley of Ajalon, which is far from Gibeon, for Gibeon is within the borders of Benjamin [in the south], and Ajalon is within the borders of Dan [in the north].

text.title: Is it not written [already] in the book of Jashar?:

pasuk.text: This matter is written in the Torah [i.e., the Pentateuch] that Jacob said to Joseph, “His seed [of Ephraim] will fill the nations.” When? On the day that the sun stood still for Joshua, the entire world was filled with Joshua’s fame, and the sun stood still in the midst of the heaven, and it did not hasten to go down exactly a whole day."
Heb. גֹּלּוּ, “roll (גַּלְגְּלוּ) great stones onto the mouth of the cave.”

text.title: none whetted his tongue against any of the children of Israel:

pasuk.text: This is a short verse, [the subject being absent in the original, meaning] no whetter whetted his tongue to any of the children of Israel.

Heb. חָרַץ, an expression meaning speech of the tongue, and so: “no dog whetted (יֶחֱרָץ) its tongue.” And so: “Then shall you shout (תֶּחֱרָץ) ,” stated concerning David, “You shall call out, you shall shout a battle cry.”
the place where the water of the hills pours down.

This is from the south side of Eretz Israel from east to west. He was, however, unable to conquer the entire boundary, thus there remained from Gaza to the [Mediterranean] Sea. This is what the Scripture states below: “This is the land that yet remained… the Gazathites, and the Ashdodites, etc.”
south of Ginosar.

text.title: and in the region of Dor:

pasuk.text: the provinces of Dor, Contree in French.
Jonathan renders: Ditches of the sea, for they would make ditches, into which the sea water would flow and burn up [evaporate] from the heat of the sun, and become salt.
Jonathan renders: whose walls were not destroyed, like Jericho, whose walls fell, and so Ai, concerning which it is stated: “And made it a heap forever, a desolation.”
because of a tradition he burned it. Moses commanded and transmitted it to him. In Genesis Rabbah , in the portion entitled: And Jacob sent.
the plain of Gad.

text.title: Joshua made war a long time with all these kings:

pasuk.text: This sentence is a rebuke to Joshua for he intended to delay the conquest of the Land in order to lengthen his lifespan, for it was stated: “And you shall cause them to inherit it.”
For there was the border of the land of the children of 'Ammon, the edge of the territory of the land of she children of 'Ammon, and from there on, the children of 'Ammon were ruling.

text.title: and half Gilead, the border of Sihon:

pasuk.text: There was the border of Sihon’s realm, as it was stated above (2) that half of Gilead was his, and this second half was 'Og’s.

text.title: there remains yet very much land:

pasuk.text: of that which I promised to Abraham remains to be possessed, for it has not been conquered.
Heb. גּלִילוֹת, marche in Old French.

i.e., the Nile synonymous with the brook of Egypt. It adjoins the southwestern border of Eretz Israel, as is stated in “וְאֵלֶּה מַסְעֵי.” We learn here that in Joshua’s lifetime, he did not conquer the entire southern border, except from the desert of Zin [which is the divided smooth mount that goes up to Seir] to the Nile. This is the boundary of Gaza which is stated above: “From Kadesh Barnea to Gaza.”

text.title: to the border of Ekron northward:

pasuk.text: The 'Ekronites dwell by the sea and spread out farther northward than the others.

text.title: which is counted to the Canaanites:

pasuk.text: i.e., It is a part of the land of Canaan which I gave to Abraham.

text.title: the five lords of the Philistines:

pasuk.text: This is the end of the border to the Mediterranean Sea which is in the west.

text.title: the Gazathites, and the Ashdodites, etc.:

pasuk.text: He enumerates six, yet in the beginning he calls them five. Said Rabbi Johanan: [He counts] their prominent ones. The prominent ones were five, for he does not count the 'Avim among the prominent lords. We may also explain thus: The five lords of the Philistines: The Gazathites, and the Ashdodites, and the Ashkelonites, and the Gittites, and the Ekronites, these are the five. And there also remained to conquer, the land of the 'Avim who are not of the Philistines.

text.title: From the south, all the land of the Canaanites:

pasuk.text: The preceding verse describes [the region] from the south side from east to west, and this verse describes the width of that region, which remained to conquer, how much it was from south to north. [Thus we explain]
From the south, i.e., Mearah that belongs to the Sidonians, to Aphek, to the Amorites.

text.title: And the land of the Giblites, and all the Lebanon, toward the sunrising:

pasuk.text: And on the eastern border, there remained to conquer in the northern end, all the Lebanon, from Baal-Gad to the end of the border, and in the width from east to west, to the entering into Hamath. This is the entire northern boundary, for the entering into Hamath is at the northwestern corner, in “ אֵלֶּה מַסְעֵי.”
after your death.

text.title: only divide it by lot to the Israelites as an inheritance:

pasuk.text: and subsequently, each tribe will conquer that which fell into its lot.
i.e., with the first half tribe of Manasseh, the Reubenites and Gadites received their inheritance.
He goes on to describe the entire land on the other side of the Jordan, after which he explains the boundary of each tribe. And Moses gave to such and such a tribe, etc.

text.title: who remained of the remnant of the giants [Rephaim]:

pasuk.text: whom Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him had slain, as it is stated: “And they smote the Rephaim in Ashteroth Karnaim.”
This follows Jonathan.

text.title: and half the land of the children of 'Ammon:

pasuk.text: half of what they conquered of the land of the children of 'Ammon and (sic) from Sihon.
the cities which are on its bank.
the walled cities.
open cities without walls.
[lit.,] caused to inherit.

text.title: For the children of Joseph were two tribes:

pasuk.text: instead of the tribe of Levi.

text.title: as it was in my heart:

pasuk.text: and not as it was in my mouth, for the spies were of one counsel, and Caleb was afraid to say to them that he would not say the same as they. But, when he came, he contradicted them. That is what is stated there: “Because there was another spirit with him,” for he said to them one version with his mouth, while he had another version in his heart.

We learn that the conquest of the land took seven years, for in the second year, Moses sent the spies. There remain thirty- eight years, during which the Israelites walked through the wilderness, and seven in which they conquered [the land], making a total of forty-five years.

text.title: Arba was the greatest man among the Anakim:

pasuk.text: Arba was the name of the father of Ahiman, Sheshai and Talmai. Another explanation is: [It was called Kirjath-arba, the city of four] because of the father and the three sons for the scripture calls them the children of 'Anak.

text.title: And the land had rest from war:

pasuk.text: This refers back to the previous topic, i.e., after the seven years during which they conquered their surroundings the Amorites were humbled and no longer gathered to wage war upon them. Therefore they began to engage in the division of the land. The Midrash Aggadah states that the greatest man among the 'Anakim was our father Abraham who was instrumental for them that the land rested from war the forty years that they tarried in the wilderness as a reward for that which they honored the patriarch in Kiriath-arba, for they said to him. ’A Godly prince are you in our midst.’
Adjacent to the border of Edom.
at the southern boundary of Eretz Israel.

text.title: at the uttermost part of the south:

pasuk.text: at the end of the entire boundary.
i.e., the southern border of Judah.

text.title: from the edge of the Salt Sea:

pasuk.text: that is the southeastern corner of Eretz Israel, in אֵלֶּה מַסְעֵי.
[lit., the tongue, i.e., the tongue] of the sea.

text.title: And it went out to the south side of Maaleh-Acrabbim [Scorpion Pass]:

pasuk.text: The Scripture uses the terms: וְיָצָא and it went out, וְתָאַר, and it circled וְנָסַב, and it circled, only where the line of the boundary bulges outward, or is indented, and does not follow a straight course. Here, it bulges outward, and comes מִנֶּגֶב לְמַעֲלֵה עַקְרַבּים to the south of Maaleh-Acrabim. Hence, Maaleh-Acrabbim is within the line, and it passed it and continued westward.
Heb. צִנָּה, same as לְצִין, Every word which needs a ‘lamed’ prefixed to it, may instead have a ‘he’ suffixed to it.

As long as it ascends from the east toward Jerusalem, it ascends, and from Jerusalem and further, it descends. Hence, we learn that Jerusalem is the highest point in all Eretz Israel. Jerusalem is not mentioned in this boundary, for it was in the northern border of Judah, as is mentioned in this chapter.

text.title: and ascended on the south side of Kadesh-Barnea:

pasuk.text: The line goes to the south of Kadesh-Barnea. Hence, Kadesh is within the line.

text.title: and it passed along to Hezron:

pasuk.text: He continues to count westward until: and its goings out (sic) were at the sea.

the end of the border is at the Great [Mediterranean] Sea which is the western border of all Eretz Israel. Hence, the boundary of Judah occupies the entire length of Eretz Israel from east to west, and is situated in the south of Eretz Israel.
the line which is drawn along the east border of Judah.
which is the southeastern corner of the land, in “Eileh Massei.”

text.title: even to the end of the Jordan:

pasuk.text: The breadth of the boundary of Judah is only opposite the Dead Sea, up to the place where the Jordan empties into the Dead Sea, for the Jordan too is in the eastern border of the land of Canaan, as it is stated in “Eileh Mass’ei,” concerning the eastern border; and the border descended to the Jordan, and its goings out were the Salt Sea, which is at the corner.

text.title: And their border in the north quarter:

pasuk.text: The borderline which is drawn along the northern border from east to west, is from the gulf of the Dead Sea, from the place where the Jordan empties into it, as we have stated that the eastern border ends there; and it went up westward to Beth Hoglah, and the line passed on the north of Beth-Arabah in the south of Eretz Israel. Beth-Arabah (sic) hence, Beth Arabah is in the boundary of Judah, within the line.

text.title: and the border went up to Eben of Bohan:

pasuk.text: As long as the border goes toward Jerusalem, it goes up.

text.title: And the border went up toward Debir from the Valley of Achor:

pasuk.text: for the Valley of Achor was between Eben of Bohan and Debir.

And when the border reached opposite Gilgal, the border widens and the borderline goes out toward the north to Gilgal which is opposite the ascent to Adummim, the ascent being south of the valley. Hence, the valley is outside the line, not in the boundary of Judah.

text.title: on the south side of the valley:

pasuk.text: This was a steep canyon without water.
the fountain of the launderers, according to Jonathan who renders: קַצְרָה עֵין. The scripture calls the launderer רוֹגֵל, because he treads woolen clothing with his feet (רֶגֶל).

text.title: And the border went up by the valley of the son of Hinnom:

pasuk.text: It still goes up a little until 'En-’etam, and from there on it goes down. Now, this is what our Rabbis said in Zeb. : “They thought to build it [the Temple] in 'En-’etam, which is slightly higher than Jerusalem.”

text.title: to the south side of the Jebusite: the same is Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: Jerusalem is found to be outside the line, and not in the boundary of Judah, but in the boundary of Benjamin, which is north of Judah.
Heb. וְתָאַר an expression similar to וְנָסַב, in a circle, like: “And with a compass he encircles it.” יְתָאֳרֵהוּ Jonathan rendered them all וְיִסְחַר, and he encircled.

text.title: and it went out to, etc.:

pasuk.text: The line goes out to the north, and the boundary widens to the cities of Mount Ephron.

text.title: and the border circled to Baalah:

pasuk.text: This is not to the west, but the bulge was to the north.

text.title: And the border compassed from Baalah westward:

pasuk.text: Now he returns to his previous enumeration [of border cities] from east to west.

text.title: to the side of Mount Jearim, etc.:

pasuk.text: for the borderline was north of Mt. Jearim. Hence, Mt. Jearim is within the boundary of Judah, within the borderline.

text.title: and the goings out of the border:

pasuk.text: the end of the boundary.
at the Great [Med.] Sea which is the western boundary.

text.title: according to the commandment of the Lord to Joshua:

pasuk.text: as the Most Holy, Blessed be He, said to Joshua.

text.title: And Caleb drove out of there:

pasuk.text: after Joshua’s death, for during Joshua’s lifetime Hebron was not yet taken, as it is stated in Jud. It was only written here because of its relation to the division [of the land].
Our Rabbis said: These are the [3,000] laws which were forgotten during the mourning period for Moses, which Othniel the son of Kenaz reestablished through his great scholarship.
from his mother.
Heb. וְאִתְרְכִינַת (Targum) She bent herself to fall at his feet.
Heb. בְרָכָה.
Heb. נֶגֶב, like: “the face of the ground was dried,” which Onkelos renders: נגיבו. Sec in French. I.e., a house which is arid [devoid] of all earthly good, a man who has nothing but Torah.

Heb. נתתני, i.e., you have given to me [but the preposition is lacking in Hebrew]. Like: “To speak to him (דַּבְּרוֹ) peacefully,”;“my children have gone forth from me (יְצָאֻנִי)”; “he cooked for them (וּבִשְּׁלָם) the meat.”

text.title: And the uttermost cities of the tribe of the children of Judah:

pasuk.text: on the border of the tribe of Judah. That is what our Rabbis said: Joshua only enumerated the towns on the borders [of every tribe].

When you count them, you find thirty-eight. These extra were taken by the children of Simeon from the territory of the children of Judah, and they are mentioned in the inheritance of Simeon: Beer-sheba, and Moladah, and Hazar-shual, and Ezem, and Eltolad, and Hormah, and Ziklag, and Ain, and Rimmon. These are the extra nine enumerated here.

When you count them, you find fifteen. I say that Tappuah and Enam are one, and this is its explanation: Tappuah and its spring. That is 'En-tappuah which is mentioned in reference to the inheritance of Manasseh: 'to the inhabitants of ‘En-tappuah.’
the islands in the sea [adjacent to the coast], isles in old French.

text.title: the children of Judah could not drive them out:

pasuk.text: We learned in Sifrei : Rabbi Joshua the son of Korha says: They really could, but they were not permitted, because of the oath which Abraham had sworn to Abimelech. Now these Jebusites were not of the Jebusite nation, but the Tower of David which was in Jerusalem, was called Jebus, and the inhabitants of that section were of the Philistines. And when the children of Judah conquered Jerusalem, they did not drive out the inhabitants of that section.

text.title: And the lot for the children of Joseph went out:

pasuk.text: At the northern boundary of the end of Joshua’s conquest, the lot fell for them, as he states below: “and the sons (sic) of Joseph shall remain in their border on the north.” [Should read: “And the house of Joseph.”] Now much of the land was between the children of Judah and the children of Joseph, which the remaining tribes took after them, [or between them], as we find concerning the tribe of Benjamin: “and the border of their lot went out between the children of Judah and the children of Joseph.”

text.title: from the Jordan at Jericho, to the water of Jericho on the east:

pasuk.text: I.e., here the border started on the east.

text.title: to the wilderness that goes up from Jericho:

pasuk.text: To the wilderness, it [the border] goes up from Jericho and comes westward to Beth-el.

text.title: on the east side was 'Atroth- addar:

pasuk.text: “To the east it starts from 'Atroth-addar,” and from there was the width of his boundary to Beth horon; this is its width.

text.title: And the border went out toward the west:

pasuk.text: Its length was to the west side, to Michmetath; the line went on the north of Michmetath.
The width of the boundary spread out toward the north, and the line went out with its bulge to the east of Taanath-shiloh.

And the border passed Taanath-shiloh, and the line passed on the east of Janoah. All this is the bulge of the width until “And went out at the Jordan.” And there is a city named Tappuah, and from there the line turned about to the measure of the length of the border westward to the stream of Kanah.
And this too is still of the inheritance of Ephraim: They had cities separated from their boundary, and enveloped by the inheritance of the children of Manasseh.

text.title: for Machir the firstborn of Manasseh:

pasuk.text: Therefore, he took first in Moses’ days on the other side of the Jordan, and had Gilead and Bashan.

text.title: And there fell ten portions to Manasseh:

pasuk.text: i.e., six for the six fathers’ houses enumerated above, and four for the daughters of Zelophehad, not that each one should be considered an individual father’s house, [for they were five - Kara] but they received four shares: (1) The share of their father who was one of those who left Egypt, and according to the number of those who left Egypt the land was apportioned; (2) and his share with his brothers in the property of Hepher, who was also one of those who left Egypt; and (3) he was the firstborn, and received two portions; and (4) in addition, they had the share of their father’s brother, who died in the wilderness without children, and they received inheritance in his share. Our Rabbis stated this in Baba Bathra . It was not necessary for the scripture to relate to us the number of the daughters’ shares, except to teach us that they received the firstborn share, and to inform us that Eretz Israel was an inherited share which belonged to them from the time of their forefathers, for otherwise, the firstborn does not receive an extra share of that which is fit to come into the father’s possession, as he does in that which the father had already acquired.

text.title: and the rest… had the land of Gilead:

pasuk.text: i.e., the rest of Manasseh’s sons had the land of Gilead which was on the other side of the Jordan.
i.e., the villages and suburbs, but the city of Tappuah itself, belonged to the children of Ephraim.
on the boundary of Manasseh, at the end of his border.
from Tappuah to the brook of Kanah belonged to Ephraim among the cities of Manasseh.
Ephraim received his share from the south, toward the land between the children of Judah and the rest of the tribes.
Manasseh received the land to the north.

“three provinces” (Jonathan). The three regions mentioned here were of Dor and 'En-dor, as aforementioned in this book: “The king of Dor of the regions of Dor,” and in another verse the Scripture states: “and in the regions of Dor on the west.” And here the Scripture states: “The inhabitants of Dor and her towns,” which were the three regions that belonged to her.
Heb. וַיּוֹאֶל, was willing.

text.title: And the children of Joseph spoke:

pasuk.text: i.e., The tribe of Manasseh.

text.title: forasmuch as the Lord has blessed me thus?:

pasuk.text: Forasmuch as you have seen that my number has increased from the first count to the second count by 20,500, signified by the numerical value of כֹּה (25). In the first count you find in Manasseh in the book of Numbers 32,200, and in the Sidrah Pinchas, 52,700. Another explanation is: forasmuch as the Lord has blessed me even until כה, the blessing which was bestowed on Abraham: (“So כֹּה) shall be your seed,” was fulfilled in me. And according to peshat, forasmuch as the Lord has blessed me thus, as you see.

text.title: If you are a numerous people:

pasuk.text: you have strength to cut down forests and to clear them, similar to that which we call essarter in French, and there you shall build cities.
Heb. וּבֵרֵאתָ, an expression of cutting, like: And they will cut them (וּבָרֵא אוֹתְהָן) with their swords, essarteras in French.
Heb. אָץ.
For it is too confined for us, as you said.
Heb. לֹא יִמָּצֵא.

and what you say, to go up to the forest and to conquer in the land of the Perizzites and the giants [Rephaim], is no easy task, for those Canaanites are a mighty nation and have iron chariots. Do not wonder if the Scripture calls the Perizzites and Rephaim Canaanites, for they were all children of Canaan.

text.title: But the mountain shall be yours:

pasuk.text: the one concerning which I said to you, “go up to the forest.”

text.title: for it is a forest, and you shall cut it down:

pasuk.text: for it is a forest, and it is only fit for a numerous people, who will cut it down and clear it.

text.title: and you shall cut it down:

pasuk.text: for you are a great people.

text.title: for you shall drive out the Canaanite:

pasuk.text: since you are a great people.
and none of the other tribes is big enough to wage war with him.
and you have the ability, and must drive him out. Our Rabbis explained: Go up to the forest - Hide in the forests lest the evil eye have power over you.

text.title: and set up the tent of meeting there:

pasuk.text: which they had constructed in the wilderness. There was no ceiling, but a stone structure below, and curtains above. This we learned in Tract. Zeb. .

text.title: And the land was subdued before them:

pasuk.text: since the Tabernacle was permanently established, the Land became much easier for them to conquer.

for Reuben, Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh had already received their inheritance in the days of Moses on the other side of the Jordan; and in the land of Canaan, the lot had already fallen for Judah, and Ephraim, and for the other half tribe of Manasseh. Thus, five tribes were provided for.
Heb. מִתְרַפִּים.
I.e., for each tribe of the seven.

into seven parts, not equal ones, but in proportion to the size of the tribes, to the larger tribe according to its largeness, and to the smaller tribe according to its smallness, as is stated: “To the larger, you shall give a larger inheritance, etc.”

text.title: and they shall divide it into seven parts:

pasuk.text: both that which has already been conquered, and that which is yet to be conquered.

text.title: Judah shall remain in his border on the south:

pasuk.text: of Eretz Israel, for there fell to his lot the entire southern boundary.

text.title: and the house of Joseph… on the north:

pasuk.text: I.e., the north of the already conquered land. There is, however, much more to conquer: The side of the boundary from Baal-gad to the coming to Hamath, which is near Mount Hor, in the northern boundary, and the seven tribes shall divide that which is between Judah and Joseph, and also that which is yet to be conquered.
Heb. וְיָרִיתִי, and I will cast [or throw], like: “He cast into the sea.”

text.title: And their border on the north side was from the Jordan:

pasuk.text: and their northern border was the Jordan, for the border started at the east, and went up to the side of Jericho on the north, i.e., it went up from there westward to the side of Jericho, and the line is drawn on the north of Jericho. Hence, Jericho is within the line, in Benjamin’s part.
Heb. מִדְבָּרָה בֵּית אָוֶן.
westward.

text.title: to Luz, to the side of Luz, which is Beth-el, southward:

pasuk.text: the city which Jacob called Beth-el. This is not the city of Beth-el which is near Ai, for the Scripture states regarding the border of Joseph: “And it went out from Beth el to Luz.” Hence, we deduce that there were two. Now, Luz was not in Benjamin’s territory, for the borderline was on the inner side of Luz, as the Scripture states “to the side of Luz… southward.” The line goes south of Luz; hence, Luz is outside of the line, in the inheritance of the children of Joseph, while Beth-el is in the territory of Benjamin, as is stated below in this chapter.

text.title: And the border was circled, and encompassed the west side southward:

pasuk.text: in 'Atroth adar, the length of the northern boundary from east to west, ends; and from there, the line encompassed the western border of Benjamin to go southward, i.e., from north to south. The western borderline extended from the hill that lies before Beth horon, southward, i.e., from the hill which lies south of Beth-horon, from there began the northwest corner of Benjamin, and the borderline went from north to south.

i.e., his south-western corner, was at Kirjath-jearim which belonged to Judah. Hence, the width of Benjamin’s boundary occupies the entire width of the land between Judah and Ephraim. His southern border coincides with Judah’s northern border, where Jerusalem was situated, as it is stated further in this chapter; therefore, both tribes had a share in it. Benjamin’s northern border coincides with Ephraim’s southern border, and there was Shiloh in Ephraim’s territory, as it is said: “And He despised the tent of Joseph, and the tribe of Ephraim He did not choose.” Benjamin too, had a share in it, as we learned in Tractate Zeb. : In three places did the Divine Presence rest in Israel: In Shiloh, and Nob [and Gibeon, counted with Nob as one place], and the Temple, and in all of them, it rested only in the part belonging to Benjamin.
the west side from Atroth-adar to Kirjath-jearim

and the southern boundary of Benjamin which is identical with the northern boundary of Judah. All the borders enumerated here, have been enumerated in reference to the north of Judah, and every place which is described here as going down, is described in reference to Judah as going up, because here he counts from west to east, and there he counts from east to west.

text.title: and the border went out to a sea:

pasuk.text: Heb. יָמָּה, to a sea, and I do not know which sea this is.

text.title: at the bay of the Salt Sea to the north:

pasuk.text: to the north of the bay. Hence the entire bay is in Judah’s territory.

text.title: at the… end of the Jordan:

pasuk.text: the place where the Jordan empties into the Dead Sea. This was described as the north-eastern corner of Judah, and here the Scripture describes it as the south-eastern corner of Benjamin.

text.title: And the Jordan borders it on the east side:

pasuk.text: i.e., the Jordan was the eastern boundary of Benjamin, for the Jordan runs opposite the width of his entire boundary on the east.

text.title: And Zelah, Eleph, and the Jebusite, which is Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: Each one is a separate city, and so are Gilbeath and Kiriath, totaling five cities in this verse.

text.title: And the second lot came out:

pasuk.text: i.e., second to that of Benjamin, for Benjamin’s lot was the first of the seven tribes whose messengers Joshua charged with: “And they shall divide it into seven parts,” for Judah and Joseph had already received their parts, as it is stated there: “Judah shall remain in his border on the south.” From here on, he proceeds to enumerate seven lots.
lit., more than they more than was fit for them.

I believe that this is an expression of “flanks” (כְּסִלִים), flancs in French [as in Lev. III:4], not at its peak, nor at its base, but on its slope near the middle, neat the rear, but on the front side, as the flanks are situated in an animal. [Thus, we render: The Flanks of Mt. Tabor.] The place which the Scripture refers to as Aznoth-tabor, is near its peak, in the place of the ears (אָזְנַיִם).
To the east of Gath-hepher, the city of Jonah the son of Amittai.
The name of the city was Ittah kazzin [not 'Eth kazzin].

text.title: and from these circled to Neah:

pasuk.text: lit., which circles to Neah, i.e., from there the border circled to Neah. Thus Jonathan rendered: And it went out to Rimmon, and from there circled to Neah.

text.title: to the fortress city of the rock:

pasuk.text: fortified cities, strong cities.
Heb. צֹר, an expression of צוּר, a rock.
lit from the rope of Achzib, from the lot of Chezib.
which belonged to Naphtali were: Ziddim, Zer, etc.
They belonged to Judah, and the lot of the children of Dan fell adjacent to them.

text.title: And the border of the children of Dan went out from them:

pasuk.text: The children of Dan took part [of their inheritance] here, and they also received a lot elsewhere far from their border, with the other tribes intervening between them.
at a later time, in the days of Othniel the son of Kenaz and in the days of Micah’s graven image, as is stated in the book of Judges.
identical with Laish mentioned in the Book of Judges.
lit., caused to inherit.

text.title: until he stand before the tribunal for judgment:

pasuk.text: If he be freed from exile he is dismissed. If, however, he is sentenced to exile, he is remanded to his refuge city, where he must dwell until the death of the High Priest.

text.title: And of the other side of the Jordan at Jericho eastward, they had assigned:

pasuk.text: during Moses’ time as it is stated: Bezer in the wilderness, etc.
lit., the cities of setting apart, those set apart for this.

text.title: And the rest of the children of Kohath:

pasuk.text: They are the children of Moses, and the children of Izhar, and Hebron, and Uzziel.

text.title: from the families of the tribe of Ephraim:

pasuk.text: These cities fell to them from the inheritance of the tribe of the children of Ephraim, for they received cities in the inheritance of each tribe, as it is stated: “From the many you shall take many, and from the few you shall take few; each tribe according to its inheritance which they inherit, shall give of its cities to the Levites.”

text.title: these cities that will be mentioned by name:

pasuk.text: Since above he did not mention the names of the cities which they gave them, and below he enumerates them, he, therefore, states: These cities that will be mentioned by name.
and in Chron.: “and 'Alemeth.” That is Bahurim which Jonathan renders: עַלְמוֹת
two thousand ells on each side.

text.title: And also when Joshua sent them away:

pasuk.text: i.e., the half tribe of Manasseh, as he had sent away the children of Reuben and Gad.

text.title: divide the spoil… with your brothers:

pasuk.text: the children of Reuben and the children of Gad. Some interpret this to mean: With your brothers who remained to guard the cities with the women and children, and did not cross the Jordan with the advance guard. They too received a share of the spoils.

text.title: to go up to war against them:

pasuk.text: For high places had been banned since the establishment of the tabernacle at Shiloh.

text.title: if the land of your possession is unclean:

pasuk.text: For the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not choose it to cause His presence to rest therein.
Heb. וְאוֹתָנוּ, instead of תִּמְרֹדוּ וּבָנוּ אַל.

God of all the divine creatures [angels], He is the Lord, who knows that not in rebellion nor in transgression, etc. The repetition of the Name of God [is for the purpose of proclaiming their belief in one God both] in this world and in the world to come.
They directed this statement toward the Divine Presence.
He will punish us.

Because of דְּאָגַת, i.e., the fear of insulting words we have done this, as the Scripture explains: Lest in time to come, your children say, to insult our children when they go to sacrifice in the Tabernacle of Shiloh, lest they say, ‘what have you to do with the Lord? Did he not place the Jordan between us and you as a border?’ We feared this, and made [the altar]. Every דְּאָגָה in the Scriptures is an expression of fear, e.g., “I fear the Jews (דֹּאֵג) of Zedekiah.”

text.title: but it is a witness between us and you.:

pasuk.text: that we have not withdrawn ourselves from the law of the altar.

text.title: and the children of Israel blessed God:

pasuk.text: And the children of Israel thanked God.

text.title: And the children of Reuben and the children of Gad called the altar: 'for it is a witness…’:

pasuk.text: This is one of the short verses. It requires the addition of one word: “And the children of Reuben and the children of Gad called the altar ‘Witness.’”

text.title: Behold, I have allotted to you:

pasuk.text: By lot for an inheritance.
to be vanquished.

They will go about (יְשׁוֹטְטוּ) to pillage and loot around you. וּלִצְנִנִים an expression meaning camps. And similar to this: “and they shall come upon you with camps (הַצַן),” like a shield (כַּצִנָּה) which encompasses a person from three sides, as it is stated: “as with a shield (כַּצִנָּה)”, “with favor (תַּעְטְרֶנּוּ) you encompass him,” similar to: “and Saul and his men were surrounding (עוֹטְרִים) David and his men.” עוֹטְרִים means surrounding [or encompassing].
Heb. וְאַרְבֶּה. defective הא (וְאַרְבּ) [from the root ריב, to quarrel] How many quarrels and tests did I cause him to endure before I gave him seed.

text.title: and brought the sea upon him:

pasuk.text: i.e., upon each individual among them, for if one escaped entering into the sea, a wave of the sea would pursue him and overtake him.

text.title: and the inhabitants of Jericho fought against you, the Amorites, and the Perizzites, etc.:

pasuk.text: All seven nations are mentioned here, since Jericho is situated on the border, and it was the bolt and lock [i.e., the fortification] of Eretz Israel, and the heroic soldiers of all the seven nations assembled therein.

Heb. אֱלֹהִים קְדֹשִים, a plural form. In most places, every expression of lordship appears in the plural form, like: “The lord of (אֲדוֹנֵי) the land”; “Joseph’s master (אֲדוֹנֵי)”, “if his master (בְּעָלָיו) is with him”;“that God (אֱלֹהִים) went (הָלְכוּ) to redeem,” because this name (אֱלֹהִים) is a name of majesty.

Joshua foresaw that they would contest [this covenant] in the days of Ezekiel, and say, “Let us be like the nations.” Therefore, he made it more difficult now. He therefore, answered them in the days of Ezekiel, “And that which enters your thoughts, shall not come to pass, etc. As I live, etc., surely with a strong hand, etc.” You have already accepted upon yourselves in the days of Joshua. And you shall not say, “The covenant which we accepted upon ourselves in the days of Moses, we did only in order to enter the Land,” for in the days of Joshua you had already entered and you [nevertheless] accepted [the covenant].

text.title: and set them a statute and an ordinance in Shechem:

pasuk.text: He arranged for them there, the statutes of the Torah, and they accepted them upon themselves.

Jonathan renders: And Joshua wrote these words and placed them in the Book of the Law of God. In the Tractate Makkoth , However, there is a divergence of opinion between two Amoraim. One says: These are the eight verses from: “And Moses died there,” until: “To the eyes of all Israel,”; for the scroll of the Law was incomplete, and he completed it. The other one says: This chapter of refuge cities he wrote in his Book, as they were written in the Book of the Law.

Heb. הָאַלָּה תַּחַת. [Jonathan renders] תְּחוֹת אַלְתָא. This is the doorpost of the entrance, as it is stated: “The doorposts (האיל) having five angles, and one measure for the doorposts.” Others say that this was the oak near Shechem, about which it is written in connection with Jacob: “And Jacob hid them [the idols and their ornaments] under the oak (הָאֵלָה).”

text.title: which is in the sanctuary of the Lord:

pasuk.text: [This was not a permanent sanctuary, but it was called “the sanctuary of the Lord,”] because they brought the Ark there, as it is stated above: “And they presented themselves before God.”

text.title: “Behold, this stone shall be a witness against us, etc.”:

pasuk.text: Jonathan paraphrases: This stone shall be to us even as the two stone tablets of the covenant, for we have made it for a witness, for the words which are written thereon are similar to the words of the Lord which He spoke to us. We can also interpret this according to its simple meaning: for it has heard the words which I have spoken to you as a messenger of the Omnipresent.

So was its name. Elsewhere the Scripture calls is Timnath heres, because they set up a figure of the sun upon his grave. [חֶרֶס means sun, as in Jud. 8:13, 14:18, Job 9:7.] I. e., this is the one who caused the sun to stand still. And anyone who passes by it, says, Woe to this one who performed such a great feat and died. Others say: its name was Timnath-heres, and why was it called Timnath-serah? Because its fruits would rot (מַסְרִיחִין) because of their great richness.
teaches us that the hill stormed forth (גָּעַשׁ) upon them to kill them, because they did not eulogize him properly.
הֶאֱרִיכוּ יָמִים. lit., Their days were lengthened but their years were not lengthened because they were punished.
From Shechem they kidnapped him; therefore to Shechem they returned him.

text.title: in the hill of Phinehas his son:

pasuk.text: Whence did Phinehas receive a part in the Land of Israel [if not from his father]? He inherited it from his wife.
